ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: knowledge of how research is being funded, presentation skills, summarizing and presenting a research paper.

I am very happy to have taken this course. I believe Peter has done a great job putting together this novel content. It exposed me to the admirative a lot of sensitive issues. I have learn things that not in standard traditional textbooks. And the class make up also allows one to see things from multiple dimensions
I learned so much. I learned more about the field that I am currently in and was exposed to different ways that I could stay involved in science, but not be at the bench per say.

I gained a lot of valuable information in regards on how funding of academic labs/research groups is done on a very detailed level. I also learned about how universities also contribute to sustainability of a lab that arent always immediately obvious. Mainly things like equipment, facility maintenance, funding of emergency research related costs, and etc. I also gained a deeper understanding & appreciation for the many financial, ethical, and legal rules & regulations that running a research lab in a university setting entails. .

Broad coverage of many problems in the realm of university research. How laws and policies affect the research being done, how it is funded, and effects on the research and work environment. How some laws were created to address specific problems in the field.

I learned the administrative business that enables the scientific enterprise in the United States; including how science is funded; how conflicts of interest are managed; how the products of research are disseminated; and how government, academia, and the private sector work together. I also learned about how policy has been and is being used to tackle issues such as harassment and bullying in academia. As a result, I feel like I can make a more informed and confident decision to pursue a career in academia.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Excellent instructor and wonderful class atmosphere, very manageable workload, interested information if you are planning on going into research

Stimulates thinking 
It is multidimensional
The course traverses academic, governance, industry, law
Open and conducive learning environment
Interaction of Undergrad and Graduate students 
Encourages and help students improve public speaking 
It focuses more on learning and thinking 
The contents are life long assets that will not be forgotten because students are reading for exams purposes
No weaknesses. This was perfect. I appreciate how things were tailored to undergrads and graduate students.
Feedback for assignments should be given more frequently, about weekly for proper digestion and commentary about the course material.

The course consists of a series of detailed discussions about the week's topic in science governance. I fully endorse this structure given that the material is full of nuance and warrants detailed discussions. Each class begins with student presentations about a selection of the week's readings, which allows the readings to inform the discussion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you like research! The instructor approaches all the subjects in this course with attention to detail, eagerness to discuss different questions and so much care and sensitivity, especially for topics like bullying.
Yes, I would recommend this as a primary elective for all of the graduate students in the BBS at Yale.

Yes I would highly encourage this course to be taken by any graduate or undergraduate students that are thinking of getting involved in the world of academic research. I say this because as a current senior PhD student, I at many points throughout the semester realized that the information I learned during any component of the class would have been very useful for a younger version of myself, whether I was a sophomore undergrad trying to get into a research lab, a graduating senior preparing to start a PhD in a research field, and even as a 1st year grad student, would have found the information extremely useful in terms of general understanding and to also help navigate some of the unspoken nuances of how to know how well funded or not a research group or university is.
